sp.l: Oh! sympathy of Hearts! My only Joy!
'Twas not less Pain to me to be forc'd from thee,
Than now 'tis Pleasure thus to meet thee kind.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh! now I hope we're met to part no more.
Let me no longer hear nor think of Absence.
Absence to some gives Relish to their Joy,
A breathing to their Pleasures; but to me
'Twas Death, when to the Monast'ry you fled,
And to be safe lay hid.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Ah! Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Madam! Fye, leave this dull Formality.
Does it suit Love of such a Growth as ours?
I shou'd abhor it, came it not from thee.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! stop this Torrent of unbounded Love.
Joy came before but like a quick'ning Shower
On a parch'd Soil, and greedily I drunk it;
But now I'm overwhelm'd, and drown'd in Joyâ€”
Thus now all Lovers lye to one another.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Dear Man, thou'rt doubly pleas'd
Now thou can'st raise me
As I wou'd thee, were but thy Fortune mine;
For thou'rt no needy younger Brother now,
Thy Laura shall no longer have the Pleasure
Of lavishing her Wealth on Love, and thee.
Indeed she cou'd not.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Extravagance of Goodness!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Alas! I fear'd that Lisbon wou'd have seen me
With those two little Orphans, my poor Children,
A forc'd Dependant on the cold loath'd Alms
Of proud upbraiding Friends: For all I've left
Is threaten'd to be seiz'd. The Thought on't damps my Joy; Wealth
But let it dye with all our former Sorrows.
I'm rich enough, since I've thy Love, that can command thy
Soon as the Priest has ratified our Contract,
Which now now your Brother's dead, and my first Year
Of Widowhood expir'd, need be no Secret.
We'll live like Gods. Say, shall we not? Methinks
Thou art not glad enough.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Excess of Joy, like that of Grief, is dumb;
" And, like vast Streams, too deep for Noise, flows silent,
" While shallow Torrents roar, then cease to be.
I fear she'll find me out.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: " But tell me, when shall be the happy Day?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Soon as some short Formalities of Law
" Have giv'n me full Possession of th' Estate,
" The best Artificers shall strain, to hasten
" The wish'd-for Time, and make our Nuptials sumptuous.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: " Then, like a Palace, we'll this House adorn.
" The Walls shall scorn with Arras to be cloath'd,
" Unless the Gold shames there the shading Silk.
" Amazing Wonders that dissemble Life
" In each Apartment, shall beguile the Gazers.
" The Spoils of India, and more distant Climes
" Shall croud, and rear their Fronts on rival Rarities,
" In antique Order, various as their Make;
" And ev'n the fragrant Wood, which in Compartments
" Floors the vast Rooms, seem proud to bear the Load.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh! Elegance in Luxury! Oh! Sex resin'd in Fancyâ€”
" To undo the other.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh! now methinks we solemnize our Nuptials,
A num'rous Train with all melodious Sounds
Salute us and the Morn. Then we, far brighter,
Ascend our Coach, or Love's Triumphal Chariot.
Garlands and Arches grace and roof our way,
And flow'ry Sweets, profusely strow'd, perfume it.
Joy in each Face, and Blessings in each Mouth.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! Theme for ever charmingâ€”To a Widow.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Then, my Ricardo, thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! then my Lauraâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The crowded Board shall tempt our num'rous Guests
With all that can indulge Luxuriant Taste.
" Conduits shall lavish Wine, and richer Liquors,
And all the Muses labour to Inchant us.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: And then at Night my Goddessâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ten thousand Tapers shall revive the Day,
While at a solemn Ball, the Pride of Lisbon
Shall shine and revelâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: And tir'd at last with all these smaller Joys,
Leave us to perfect Pleasure. Thus, my Goddess,
Thus will Ricardo ravish all thy Senses;
Unpeople th' Elements to Feast thy Taste,
To charm thy Ears, rob ev'n the Spheres of Musick,
Tire Art and Nature to regale thy Sight,
Inform thy Brain with ev'ry grateful Odor,
Thy Touch with Bliss, and ravish ev'ry Pow'r,
Till in one sence we lose the other four.

sp.speaker: 1. Monk.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What mean these Monks?

sp.speaker: 1. Monk.
sp.l: My Lord, We've weighty Business,
That claims your private Ear with utmost speed.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Some dead Man's Almsâ€”

sp.speaker: 1. Monk.
sp.l: Hear us this Moment, if you love your self.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Then follow meâ€”pray pardon me, dear Madam.
I'll strive to meet you here again this Momentâ€”
Or at your own House rather.

sp.speaker: To himself.]
sp.l: 'Twas well dissembl'd: But I'm glad I'm eas'd.
How loath'd a thing must a fond Woman be!
Ev'n Monks are welcome, when from her they free.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Curs'd be the Holy Duns! Those bold Intruders
Into the Privacies of blinded Mortals,
Self-privileg'd to break-in on the Great!
Those craving Idlers, who preach Charity,
Yet never had one Spark for one another!
Presumptuous Beggars, who with Saint-like Mein,
With proud Humility, and sawcy Meekness
Can seem at best but impudently good.
The Doatards know (for well they know our Sex)
That what a Woman never will forgive
Is an Intruder, whose preventing Words
Force from her Arms her Lover to remove,
In the wild Sallies of unfinish'd Love.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: WHy do we leave Fabiano with Placentia?
I dare trust all his Vertues, but his Prudence.
He lovesâ€”he'll stay too long, and be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Fear not, my Brother's busie with two Fathers;
And tho' Placentia loves, she shuns her Lover;
Like him she languishes, unhappy Maid;
But her Discretion, and yet more her Vow,
Force that despairing Lord for ever from herâ€”
And see, she comes; he follows;â€”both in Tears!
In pity let's avoid 'em.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Stay, cruel Maid! Oh turn, and cast one look!
One look, tho' 'twere a Frown, and but to see me dye.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Alas, I dare not, must not meet your Eyes:
They must not see how mine partake their Sorrows.
Fly, fly, my Lord, where equal Greatness calls
Leave poor Placentia to her humble Fate.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Not hear me!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I dread those Words that make ev'n ruine please,
The tempting Musick of your Syren Love.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Can it bring ruine to be match'd to Greatness?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: When by the Match that Greatness is debas'd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Why will you still urge this, too humble fair?
Oh! wrong not thus your Merit, and my Love.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Witness, ye sacred Pow'rs that read my Soul!
Witness, my Blushes, and these grateful Tears,
How much I prize you, gen'rous, dear Fabiano!
For ev'ry Sigh you breath, I Sigh another.
Oh! had our Births been equal as our Passions,
We might have lov'd on still.
I see the Heav'n of Joy, your Love, wou'd give me;
But, like a Wretch condemn'd to endless Torments,
The vast abyss between, adds to my Pain:
I wish, I sigh, I grieve, I rage in vain;
I wou'd ascend, but cannot break my Chain.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Love equals all, and you're most sure of mine.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I still shou'd fear to lose what I deserve not,
Still dread my Equal's Envy, and the Scorn of yours:
And thus shou'd live more wretched yet than now,
This fatal now, that sees me tear my Heart,
While thus I tear my self for ever from you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You tear my Heart, but shall not tear me from you.
Thus you shall drag me, while I suffer Life;
And when I've eas'd my wretched Soul with this,
'Twill hover o're you still, to wait for yours.
For sure in Death we're equal, and may joyn.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! hold! and rise! fright me not with your Danger,
Nor humble me yet more with your Submissions.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Raise then at once a Wretch to Love and You.
To rise thus, I'll descend, and mix with humble Swains,
In lowly Cottages, and rustick Weeds,
And there forget that fatal thing call'd Greatness.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! rise, degrade it not by kneeling thus.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: No, let your Answer make me rise or fall.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Alas! my Lord, I know this wou'd but prove
A Dream, that might a while indulge your Fancy,
While Mem'ry wou'd lye lock'd in the first sleep
That Love might lull it too; but too too soon
You'd wake to hatred of your self and me.

div.stage: Enter D. Ferdinand. Fab. starts and rises.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My Son!
Base Man! I thought t'have found you with Morella!
But hear me swear; By my great Ancestors!
That Hour Fabiano weds below his Rank
Makes him a Stranger to my Blood for ever.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: You might have spar'd that just, but rigid Doom,
And left my Love the Glory of our parting.
For, Sir, I love your Son; so well I love him,
That rather than I'll curse his gen'rous Passion,
By suffering him to bless me with himself,
I'll leave my Wealth, Friends, nay, the dear Man for ever.
Bear witness, you whose Breasts confess the Pangs
Of truest, te nd'rest, fondest, fiercest Love!
Bear witness, Heav'n! and all that hear me swear!
I leave ev'n him, ev'n all that's kind and dear,
For endless Grief, a Cloyster and Despair.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: My Love!â€”my Father!â€”both conspire my Ruine!
Some Angel stop her, and recall your Vows!
No pityâ€”yes, you're kind, at once you kill me,
And thus will quickly end the worst of Pains.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Unequal Nuptials show not Love, but Madness.
If you're my Son, leave this ignoble Creature.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Leave her! ignoble! give me Patience, Heav'n!
And Duty check my Rage! a Father said it.
Oh! that you knew her, Sir! you'd see in her,
That Worth, whence true Nobility began:
She claims a Birth immediately from Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No more. She never shall be yours.
Haste to Morella, Noble, and more Charming.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Ah Sir! I can love nothing but Placentia.
Rather take back the wretched Life you gave me!
Draw, draw your Sword, rip up my panting Bosom;
You'll find a Heart where that sad Truth is written.
Pity my Youth! pity your Son!â€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis vainâ€”Reason and Time will bring you to your self.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh stay!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Awayâ€”comply, or never see me more.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes, cruel Father; yes, unkind Placentia,
I'll never see you moreâ€”
You shall not see how wretched you have made me.
I've one Friend yet, I hope; his Ship shall cast me
On some abandon'd Shore: There I will dye;
Pitied, perhaps, by Beasts more kind than Man.
More wise, more happy Brutes, I envy you!
With you 'tis Will and Beauty make the choice,
Ne're crost by the lov'd Female, nor your Syres.
No dream of Greatness bars your am'rous Joys.
Curst be the first who made the vain distinction,
Taught to boast borrow'd Fame from ancient Dust,
That fancied Distance between equal Emmets!
Curst be the poys'nous Notion, and may he
That slights true Merit for a vain Degree,
Love humble Worth, be scorn'd, or curs'd like me.
And that the Vice an ampler Curse may find,
Curst be th' Ambitious, which is all Mankind.

div.stage: Enter Placentia, as Fabiano goes off.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: His busie Grief usurp'd his very Sight.
He's gone, and cou'd not see me; wou'd he had!
Alas! I shou'd, I wou'd have call'd, but cou'd not.
Who will protect me now?â€”Oh! noble Moor,
Assist me to preserve my threaten'd Honour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Can worth, like yours, want a Protector, Madam?
My best Friend us'd me so to eccho back his Sighs,
When he repeated dying Tales of you,
That he has fill'd my Breast with the like Zeal
Of serving you: That Zeal may look like Love;
But, fear not, Madam, rarely Love gets in
But at some Chink where Hope had crept in first,
And I who know how you us'd Don Vincentio
Can never hope this Figure cou'd prevail.
Then give me leave to serve you, and my Actions
Shall ne're oppose the Dictates of your Will.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: It were a Sin to doubt your Honour, Sir.
Let your Man waitâ€”and I will tell you Things
That are yet Secrets to all Souls but mine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Zemet observe who comes, and give us notice.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Let guilty Persons blush: I have no Cause:
The Passion I must own admits no Shame;
Tho' I confess, I Love: Oh Noble Moor!
You will have Cause to pity me as much
As e're you did Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Do I live?â€”
Or have I chang'd my Being with my Form?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: What shou'd surprize the Moor?â€”Sir, tho' I want
Your help, or such a Friend's, yet let not that
Divert your Thoughts from your own great Concerns.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: No, Madam, these are Fits that sometimes shake me:
My Soul and Body are by turns at odds,
And fain wou'd part;
Yet, like false Friends, each strives not to be thought
To give most Cause for such a Separation:
But now I'm well againâ€”you say you Love, Madam,
And that I shall have Cause to pity you.
Sure, he that is the Cause, is Deaf and Blind;
Else either Sence, and You, might teach him Love.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Nay, I'm so miserable, worthy Moor,
That 'twas his Passion that gave birth to mine:
But, as Fate orders it, all I've to beg,
Is that you wou'd convey me to some Cloyster,
Where I may ever weep and pray for him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Sure 'tis for me, 'tis for the poor Vincentio
She thus wou'd weep and pray. Oh wou'd it were!
Madam, I'm bound to wait on your Commands;
But can there be a Cause for such Despair?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Too many, Sir, for had not Fate contriv'd
To snatch him, and all Hopes, for ever from me,
Yet I too well regard his future Glory,
E're to have fullied it with my mean Blood.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: 'Tis my selfâ€”
It can be no Man else she thus despairs for.
First she shall name me, then I'll own my self.
Madam, you may well trust me with his Name,
That can be happy thus in spight of Fate.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I will not hide his Name, from one that knows
So much of his Concerns: 'Tisâ€”

sp.speaker: Zem.
sp.l: Ricardo's coming.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Heav'n guard me from his sight!â€”

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: I'll strive to meet you here again with speed.
Curse on his coming! But why am I troubl'd?
By what she said, 'tis plain 'tis me she means.
Revive, Vincentio! Doubts and Fears remove!
She must be mine, since she confesses Love.
The Man that's lov'd, of Conquest never fails:
Love pleads, and bribes, and forces, and prevails.

sp.speaker: Zem.
sp.l: Ricardo seem'd dejected; I'll observe him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: This Mine brings Instant ruine when 'tis sprung;
It rends the main Foundation of my Greatness.

sp.speaker: Sees Zemet.]
sp.l: Ha! thou black Imp, what do'st thou here?
Hence vanish!
They and their Papers will so prove the Thing,
There will be no out-facing itâ€”Oh curst Discovery!
This Morning in the Sanctuary I trembl'd.
E're Noon I revel'd as sole Master here:
Yet now, e're Six at Night, these Monks have rung
A fatal Knell to all my new-born Joys.
With this Day's Sun my Fortune rose and falls.
But with the next may it not rise again?
They've giv'n me time to get my Pardon seal'd,
E're they divulge the Truthâ€”I'll have them kill'dâ€”
But how? by this they're in their Cells at Prayers.
No, I must think againâ€”assist me, Hell,â€”I have it.
At Night for Africa I'll Ship the Sisters,
Where I will marry one, and then return.
But why not get Placentia? There I'll fix:
Placentia shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hah!â€”

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Does your Guilt make you start?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Art thou Immortal, Moor?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes, Ravisher, all good Men are Immortal.
Death is entail'd on none but such as you,
Who wear him still about you in your Crimes,
Yet justly fear him as the greatest Evil.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Placentia has inform'd him of my Threats.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Base Man, with Gyant Blood, and Pigmy Honour,
I hear thou talk'st of Ravishing Placentia,
But if thou dar'st but wish it, that bad Soul,
That Soul of thine, hard and impenetrable
To ev'ry thing that's good, shall be let out
To seek its place among relentless Devils.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Sleep my Resentments! now my Fortune's chang'd.
I loath the Thought, tho' once I threaten'd it,
To try her Vertue; but, since that, my Doubts
Are chang'd to admiration of her Worth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh that there were but hopes you yet wou'd mend!
I'm bound, and strive to love you, as you're call'd
Vincentio's Brother, and his Father's Son.
In War's brave School, your Father was my Master;
Who bad me dare, and taught me how to Fight.
He rush'd like Light'ning on firm Troops of Foes,
Unnerv'd their Ranks, and shatter'd them to Ruine,
And floor'd the Field with honourable Slaughter:
But after Conquest, mild as tender Virgins,
Protected Vertue in his very Foesâ€”
If you'll be Noble, learn to act like him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll learn of you, brave Moor, if you will teach me,
Your words can shame and charm us into Vertue.
Methinks your Tongue, like glorious Victory,
Instils a Soul of Valour through my Veins,
And all my Nerves seem knit with double force.
I'm now engag'd, but in an Hour,
I shall be proud of being taught by you,
And fixing you my Friend.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Till then, farewel.
Love truly, and I ll give you leave to hope;
For as your Love encreases, Vertue will.
'Twas Love alone first Civiliz'd Mankind,
And dull Instinct to sprightly sense refin'd.
In Savage Nakedness Man liv'd and toyl'd,
Uglier than Brutes, more wretched, and as wild;
Till Emulation to be lik'd and lov'd,
Started Invention, and the Man improv'd:
But 'tis not Love, weak Bodies to controul,
Love only triumphs o're the stronger Soul.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll strive to work thee to my purpose, Moor.
Thou'rt brave, but free and credulous to a Faultâ€”
For ruin'd Laura's good, and more for mine,
I wish Placentia may with equal ease
Be wheadled into Marriage! startling change!
She little thinks she's great, and I am nothing;
Oh! I cou'd rave and bellow Execrations.
Hell curse these Monks, emphatically curse 'emâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: My Bravoes!

sp.speaker: 1. Bravo.
sp.l: Your Lordship's Servants.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I sent for you to punish a rude Moor,
But I'll suspend a while my just Revenge:
I've business of more Moment. There's Gold for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Br.
sp.l: Thanks, my good Lord, whose Throat must we cut now?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: There's milder mischief Brooding.
Hire me a Ship, that by use of Oars
As well as Sails, may put to Sea this Night.
At any rate, by any means I must
Have it to Night, and you shall go with me.
Succeed, and your Reward shall be so great
You shall no longer skulk disguis'd; but live
At large, above the scandal of your Lives.

sp.speaker: 1. Br.
sp.l: Conclude this done, my Lord; our Friends will help us.
If by fair means we cannot get a Ship, we'll seize on one.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Success wait on my Friends!

div.stage: Enter a Servant, with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What Letter's this?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Lord, 'tis for Placentia.

div.stage: [Exit Servant, Ric. opens and reads the Letter

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Go, I'll deliver itâ€”ha! from Fabiano!â€”
How? leaving Portugal for ever! Embark this Moment!
By my hopes 'tis well!

div.stage: Enter Laura. [Ricardo seems surpriz'd, and puts up the Letter hastily.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hah!â€”my Soul's Joy, I did not expect you here.

sp.speaker: LaU.
sp.l: I read that in your Eyes, my Lord, but I
Expected you, tho' 'twas in vain, I fear.
What Letter were you reading?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: 'Tis private business.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I desire to see it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Wou'd you be made uneasie with my Cares?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Unless I see't, I shall be more uneasie.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Trust me, my Love, you need not, nay you shall not,
Tho' ev'n from you I must a while conceal it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: From me! Can you conceal it then from me?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Suppose it were a Challenge from a Foe,
Or a more dang'rous Secret from a Friend?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Say rather from a Mistress: false Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Will you still chide, and without Reason still?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: False and Ingrate, I have but too much reason;
Yet if I chide, I chide but like a Dove,
In gentle Murmurs. But urge me no longer.
Give me the Letter, for I rave to see it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What, will you still controul me like a Slave?
Will you still claim so insolent a Right?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Traytor to Gratitude, to Love, and me,
What is't I claim, but leave to be assur'd
Of thy Heart's Truth, or of its Falshood rather?
For now I've too much Cause to think thee false.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Your Jealousie, that Jaundice of your Mind,
Perverts all Objects to it's sickly Colour.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What, are my Charms then vanish'd with my Fortune?â€”
'Twas otherwise when this base Rebel languish'd at my Feet,
Trembling as Guilt, humble as begging Want;
Charm'd with a Look, transported with a smile,
And extasied with a reviving Word.
Love gently rack'd all Secrets from his Breast,
Made him live more in me than in himself,
Prevent my very Wish, and open all his Soul.
Did it not Traytor?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: It did, it shall, my Life, then pray be calmer.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And have I made thee Lord of all my Wishes,
Given thee my Wealth, and my more valued Love,
To be deny'd a Triste?
Base Man, dare but be false, dare but deny me,
I'll Sacrifice thee to my injur'd Charms,
Tho' thou wert kneeling at the very Altarâ€”
Give me the Letter.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Since nothing else will satisfie you, take it.
'Tis only from Fabiano to Placentia;
For whom he's leaving Portugal by stealth.
You see, he begs this may not yet be knownâ€”
Puzzled.] Thenâ€”I'ad a mindâ€”to try your Jealous Temperâ€”
And fear'dâ€”it might incline youâ€”to misconstrue
My Caution in thus op'ning a Love-Letter
To one that's a Dependant on my House.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Hah! sure you love her, or your guilty Mind,
Which so long labour'd for a faint Excuse,
Had ne're suggested such prepost'rous Doubts.
You seem'd surpriz'd too at my sight; your Face
Had scarce the Pow'r to shape a gay Disguise.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: To clear at once my Innocence, permit me
To send for herâ€”Who waits?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Acquaint Placentia, that I'm here, and have a Letter for her.
My Life, from yonder Closet if you please,
You may behold unseen
Our mutual hatred in her looks and mine.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: She's here! This news will strangely grieve herâ€”
You're well attended.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: So we shou'd be to come to you, my Lord.
Your Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Here's a Letter from Fabiano,â€”who's fled by Sea.

div.stage: [Gives her the Letter, she reads it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh killing News!

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Poor parted Lovers! how I pity them!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Is he then fled? fled without seeing me?
Fled my Fabiano? Oh! 'twas too too cruel.
Thy last farewel wou'd pain me worse than Death;
Yet I wou'd suffer more for one dear parting lookâ€”
But sure I wrong thee; we cou'd ne're have born it.
How my Soul mourns, Some Dream or Angel tell thee!
My Soul! oh no! 'tis fled with thee, and Grief
Alone informs this Widdow'd falling Body.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Rise, rise, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sink not beneath your Sorrows.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Let me dye here; for I've out-liv'd my self.
Break, throbbing Heart! break now! break! what, not yet!
Well, stubborn Life, I'll punish thee for lasting,
Melt thee away in Tears, and breathe thee out in Sighs;
'Till I'm grown of one Substance with my Grave.
I'll drag thee where thou shalt converse with nothing
But Walls, and Heav'n, and Sorrow, and his Image.
Off then, gay Dress! vain Pageantry, away!
Thou once lov'd House, where my Years rowl'd so smoothly,
Adieu for ever!â€”adieu, my dear, my only Friends!
Adieu to all but Grief, and the dear thoughts of him.
He's lost, he's lost, and Pleasure is no more.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Let's follow her, and strive to calm her Mind.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Prevent her going out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You see the Love between us.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Did I not dread her, I cou'd pity her,

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Grieve not for her, my Love.
A Widow'd Nymph of Course a while Despairs,
But nothing dries so soon as Woman's Tears.
Clouds dull the Sun, then fall apace in Rain,
And sprightlier Smiles adorn his Face again.
Such, now your doubts are clear'd, you shou'd appear,
And with kind Looks your Injur'd Lover chear.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Were those Doubts clear'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Unkind! now I must chide. What, Jealous still?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Still Jealous, since still Loving.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: But I've a sure way left to ease your Mind.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: How?â€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Let to Morrow be our Nuptial Day.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: To Morrow!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Yes, we'll wave tedious State. Hymen shall bless us.
Oh! let me seal that Promise on your Lips;
Thus, thus your Doubts shall all be lost in Joys,
And kiss'd away as oft as they return.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Shall I still doubtâ€”no, tho' I still had Cause,
I must believe thy dear bewitching Tongue.
Conduct me home, and oh! forgive me, my Ricardo.
I cannot bear a Rival in your Heart.
While Woman must to one confine her Love,
Why shou'd Man claim the Privilege to rove?
We cou'd dispense with Change as well as you:
Women lose more than Men by being true.
Yet tho' you blame our Sex, yours most deceives;
Man leaves us oft, but Woman seldom leaves.
Be just then, urge us not to change of Mind!
Or give us leave to rove, or be your selves confin'd.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter Placentia in a plain white Dressâ€”Morella and Melinda.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: WHy am I thus detain'd? Now in this Dress
I'm fitted for a Cloyster: Oh! Fabiano!
Thou leav'st the Land, I'll leave the World for thee.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Oh! grieve us not, by grieving thus your self.
Society in Woes will make them lighter,
But ours grow heavier while we share your Load.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I'd silence my rude Grief, wou'd it be silenc'd;
But tender Love, Love newly wean'd, and hopeless
Will, like all other Infants, pine and rage,
Tho' check'd by Reason that denies the Food.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Where, where's the Chaste Placentia? Sisters, tell her
I'll crown at last the Vertue which I try'd.
What, all in Tears? She too in this mean Dress?
You feed her Grief. Away! I say, be gone.
Leave Tears and Cloysters, Madam, to those Wretches
Whom the World leaves, and who must leave the World;
Who surfeit first, then practice Abstinence,
Turn Nuns, and then repent their rash Repentance.
'Tis true, my Brother's dead, Fabiano's gone;
But I am left more charm'd with your Perfections.

sp.speaker: Pla,
sp.l: I pray you, leave me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Look not on me as being still the same;
Behold your Convert, Madam, 'twas impossible
To love you, and love Vice, which you detest.
You, and my change of Fortune, have at last,
Made me reflect, and rous'd me into Vertue.
My Threats were but to try you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I shall rejoyce, my Lord, to find the Change,
Tho' tis ill jesting in the shape of Vice;
" For 'twill be long before I shall shake off,
" The horror that surprise stamp'd on my Soul.
In the mean time, I beg you'll give me leave
In some Retirement to compose my Mind.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! leave me not, blest Maid, " You're my good Angel,
" That bear me upwards, govern my best Thoughts,
" And bid me think of Heav'n, and view it in you.
" But, if you leave me, e're my Callow Vertue
" Grows fledg'd, and strong to soar with outstretch'd Wings,
" Too soon my dead habitual weight of Vice
" Will make me flag, and fall to worse Perdition.
" Take me now, save a Soul, confirm me yours.
" O save me, lest you answer it to Heav'n.
A Priest, a known Priest, waits to joyn our Hands.
Oh come! I will not leave you till you've blest me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: What means my Lord! Oh Heav'ns! what shall I say!
Yes, I will bless youâ€”if you'll let me go.
But as for marrying you, forbid it Love!
Forbid it Honour! and forbid it Heav'n!
" This wou'd be cursing you, and then my self.
" Change, rather change this dreadful Love to Hatred!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I've play'd the Tyrant, but I know you're mild
As a forgiving Saint. Here on my Knees,
(But that's too proud a Posture) thus then falling
With prostrate Body, and more humbled Mind,
Repentant, chang'd Ricardo, begs your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh rise, my Lord! 'twas granted e're you ask'd it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! add your Love, or let me sink for ever.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: My Lordâ–ª I must not, cannot hear you thus.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Thus have I sworn to kiss your Steps, and dye,
Unless this Day, this very Day you're kind,
Stoop to be mine, and condescend to rise.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Alas! I too have sworn, this ne're shall be.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll beg so earnestly, so humbly,â€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: My Lord, I thought you knew Placentia better.
Spare this affected Cringing! 'twou'd be vain,
Tho' 'twere not feign'd; for such a whirl of Humour,
So quick a fall from one extream to t'other,
Betrays less Love than a Distemper'd Mind.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I'm craz'd, I'm mad, mad as wild Frenzy,
To starve my noble Pride, to glut a Slave's.
Why, cruel Stars, why do I court this Creature,
This Infect, born to crawl and lick the Dust,
Till foster'd here, ungratefully to sting me?
Oh! I cou'd burst, and tear my Flesh with Rage.
But why do I not rather crush it dead?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Murther! Oh save me!â€”

div.stage: [She wou'd run off, he stops her.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: None but your self can save, or you or me.
You shall be wretched, if you'll make me so:
" For, good or bad, you now must share my Fate.
This Steel, or else this Juice, shall end us both.
sp.stage: [Shews her a Bottle and a Dagger.
sp.l: 'Tis like the poys'nous Love I suck'd from thee;
No Antidote can stop the Bane's Progression;
It creeps thro' ev'ry Vein, preys on the Blood,
And ling'ring gives a sure, tho' lazy Death.
Relent, or now I drink, and thou shalt pledge me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh Horror! hold! let's parley o're our Fate.
Give me some time, my Lord, I beg it on my Knees,
A Month, a Week, a Day; Oh Mercy! Mercy!â€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No, it must be this Instant now.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: What shall I say? I dye with Terror.
O hold! oh think of Hell, my Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hell's mild to what I feel.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I can but dye

div.stage: [He keeps the Bottle close to his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I've drank the Liquid Death. Now chuse thy Fate.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh lost! lost!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Chuse quickly, orâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! give me time to pray.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: The Poyson will do that.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I thought 'twas but to try me.
But give it me. 'Tis th' only welcome present
You cou'd have made me, and I thank you for't.
I only wish my dear, my lost Fabiano,
Thou coud'st have seen these Tears, the best return,
My niggard Fate wou'd suffer me to make thee.
Oh! if a helpless, friendless, dying Maid
May form a wish! oh hear me, hear me Heaven!
Let all the dear Man's Sorrows dye with me.
And, if another e're can love so well,
Let some chaste noble Beauty love him thus,
And make him happier than I've made him wretched.

div.stage: Enter Fabiano, thrusting away some Servants, and runs to Placentia.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Hence! Slaves! she's here.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hah!â€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Return'd!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes, here to dye. Look up, my Life, my Soul,
Placentia, see 'tis I, 'tis thy Fabiano,

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: 'Tis he; some Angel brings himâ€”my lov'd Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: My Fateâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! I forget my Fears, my Grief, my very self,
At this dear sight.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Senses awake! and thou my wand'ring Soul,
Unwind thy self out of this maze of Joy.
Art thou at large, or in Placentia's Arms?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Must I bear this? my Lord, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: To kill you, if you dare once more disturb me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You're in my House, butâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll say no moreâ€”I fear his Greatness now, tho' not
His Sword

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Tho' Love had not betray'd me into Fondness,
Revenge it self had don't, to plague this Monster;
To make his Eyes drink Jealousies worst Poyson,
More gnawing than the Draught he swallow'd now,
Or that which he design'd me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: How!â€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No Poyson, Madam, nothing but a Philtre,
A Lover's harmless Trick to fright and win you.
To ease your Mind, I'll send for her that made it.â€”
And for some others tooâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I dread his coming back.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Fear nothing, Madam,
I've a Friend waits without with some choice Men.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I thought I never shou'd have seen you more.
Where have you been? Why did you write that Letter?
Was it to break my Heart? 'twas too unkind, yet I pray'd for you.
I wou'd have dy'd, but pitying Heav'n reserv'd me
For this blest Moment, e're we part for ever,
For we must part.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Part! no, first let the Monarch part with Crowns,
The Brave with Honour, and the Saint with Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh Reason, Honour, Duty!â€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh Love! Love! Love! great Love against them all.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I've sworn to leave you; nor must I examine
Whether I shall outlive the killing loss.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: No, you will not leave me: I will ne're believe it:
Placentia loves meâ€”Placentia will not let me dye.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Sure Heav'n will forgive this Sally of a Heart,
Startled and wild with Joy, this Riot of starv'd Love,
Tho' rigid Honour dares not warrant it.
Oh! lead me quickly to the Convent, thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: She whom I sent for, Madam, will soon tell youâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Nothing that can deserve our stayâ€”farewelâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Stay, do not lead my beauteous Charge to Ruine.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: She's led from Ruine, when she's led from you.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hold! hear me! for I'll here dispute my Right.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Then somewhere else, and not with Words dispute it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Tho' now with Words, some fitter time with this.
I claim her as my due. I best deserve her.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Who e're pretends Desert, deserves her least.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: She's oblig'd to my Family.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: But I'm oblig'd to her.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You've nothing; but I've an Estate to give her.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I chuse to lose one for her. But that's little;
I'd give the Globe to bribe her to a Smile.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! cease so needless a Debate, my Lords;
Nor rate so high a worthless Maid's Esteem.
Know both, I'd sworn, before I knew your Love,
Never to wed above my Rankâ€”I'm going to a Cloyster.
Then, if you love me, shew it now, my Lords.
Be pleas'd to leave me there.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No, Madam, I'll sooner leave the World.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Let me conduct you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hold!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Forbear, or in your very House I'll kill you.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hah! Will you break the Laws of Hospitality?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Talk'st thou of Hospitality, and dar'st
Detain her there? 'tis Sacrilege and Death.
Draw, Fight, and Dye.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh hold!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Tho' I dare fight, why shou'd I leave to Chance
What Prudence can secure?
The shortness of my Sword makes you insult, butâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Give it me, and take mine.

div.stage: [Fabiano gives him his Sword, and takes his in the Scabbard.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Take it, and use it if you can.â€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! hold, my Lords!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: A broken Sword! hah! Villain!

div.stage: [He draws the Sword, which appears to be a broken Blade.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Stir not, be silent, hear me, and you're safe.
Live happy with my Sister, I with her;
But dye, if you persist t'obstruct my Bliss.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! wed her, wed her, tho' I dye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I'll yet disarm thee, Traytor.

div.stage: [Fabiano with the broken Sword strives to close with Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I wou'd not kill thee! Who waits!â€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Seize that Mad-man.

div.stage: [Fabiano snatches a Sword from one of 'em, and keeps 'em off.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What, hoa! my Friends!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Help, Murther! help!â€”

div.stage: Enter Captain, with two others, who fight Ricardo's Party.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Courage, my Lord, we're here! Slaves! Villains! dye.

div.stage: Enter Don Ferdinand, with Musqueteers, who present, and all the Combatants cease Fighting.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hold! or my Guards shall fire among you.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: 'Tis well you're come at last, my Lord, your Son
Was forcing his way out with this ungrateful Maid,
To wed her, and leave Portugal by Sea.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I scarce believ'd the Messenger you sent me:
Nay, now I scarce believe my very Eyes.
What, my Reproof, my Counsel, my Commands,
My Pray'rs, my Threats, my Oaths, all unregarded?
It cannot be; Fabiano is my Son:
My Son wou'd not at once lose Wealth, lose Honour,
Lose my Love, lose my Blessing,
A Father's Love, and Blessing, for a Trifle;
For all this he must lose, or leave this Maid,
To wed my nobler choice, the fair Morella.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thus, as to Heav'n, to you, Sir, kneels your Son;
And that Heav'n knows, I scarce can reverence it,
More than I do my Father. Oh! I'd lose
The Life you gave me, rather than your Blessing.
But Love, like mine, is deaf Necessity;
'Tis Fate it self, and who can alter Fate?
If Love's a Crime in me, 'tis its own Punishment:
For hope, that soften'd all its Pains, is lost.
Then curse me not yet more: alas! your Blessing
Is all your wretched Son has left to lose.
For soon he'll take his everlasting leave
Of Friends, of you, of her, and Life, I hope.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Rise, hear Age speak! Fabiana! Wisdom's old.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: My Lord, my Father,
Oh! let me kneeling thus attend your Will.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Rise, rise, my Son, nor let thy poor old Father
Lose the sole Comfort of his widow'd Years.
Thou art my only Child. Alas! I liv'd
But by the hopes of seeing thee renew
The â€¢â€¢â€¢ ries of our Race, by equal Marriage.
Have I for this declin'd a second Choice,
And liv'd in solitary Widowhood?
Oh! do not hurry thus thy self and me
To the dark Grave, and worse Oblivion's Death.
I beg it, 'tis thy Father begs it. See these Tears,
They're the last drops, the dying hand of Age
Has left to dew this drooping with'ring Plantâ€”Oh speak!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Can Nature plead against it self?
I cannot speak: my throbbing Heart's too full.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then kill me, cruel Son; that Parricide
Will be less barb'rous than the otherâ€”speak!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Then with obedient boldness I must own, I cannot wed Morella.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Just Heav'n! what have I done? what are my Crimes?
That I must thus be punish'd with this Son?â€”
But sure he's not my Son: Such Disobedience,
Such Meanness, must and shall be Strangers to my Blood.
Now, as I hate base Thoughts, he's rous'd my Rage.
Degenerate Boy, thou scandal to my Race,
Retract thy words, consent, lest, in my Fury,
I wrong the dead, and ev'n suspect thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh! use me as you please; but spare my Mother!
For your own sake, for hers, tread gently on her Grave.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, she was Vertue's self, but sure some Peasant
Impos'd thee on me, and displac'd the Heir.
Be banish'd then my House, my Heart, my Thoughts!
Be stript of allâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: But my Placentia's Love:
You cannot take that from me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tortures and Daggers! Wretch, lose all but that.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: My Lord, let him rave on.
He's lost all use of Reason in this Fit
Of Love's high Fever; but it cannot last.
Leave him with me, I'll watch its Crisis and Declension.
First, I'll remove the Cause, this fatal Charmer,
Then soon my Sister shall restore his Reason.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis well advis'dâ€”Guards stayâ€”obey my Lord.
Curst be this Frantick Love, that rashly hurries
Unequal Pairs into the Nuptial Noose!
How bitter proves the fair forbidden Fruit!
How lost, how naked Man then finds himself!
How short, how false the Bliss, how long the Woe;
A few good Nights, a thousand dismal Days.
Then the fierce Lover grows a tame dull Husband,
And the kind Mistress a vexatious Wife.
How like an Ass, how like himself he looks,
Wishing to part, more than he did to joyn;
While Wife and Husband curse th' unequal state,
Wedded for Love, then Cuckolded for Hate.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Retire you tempting Mischief to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! rather to a Cell.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! once more let me see him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You shall not see him more.

div.stage: [Fabiano who was talking to the Captain, runs suddenly to prevent her going out.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: See me no more? then I'm poor indeed;
Yes, I will see her, tho' her sight were Death.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hold! my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Forbear! Despair is frantick; play not with it;
I've lost all hopes but of one parting look;
Rob me not of that last, that cruel pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh rigid Fate, why must I thus undo himâ–ª
" But I my self shall soon be more than punish'd,
" Lonesome, self-banish'd, buried to the World,
" My Life shall be a kind of ling'ring Death.
" Course Weeds my Cloathing, a poor Cell my Lodging,
" Bare Walls my only prospect, the cold Ground,
" Or harder Floor, my Bed; and Grief my End.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: " Oh! why did I come back! why wou'd I see her!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Then, if at dead at Night you chance to wake,
" Oh! think of me, and say, now poor Placentia
" Is risen in the Dark, and in the Cold,
" To pray for me, to pray for her Fabiano:
" For then will I be praying on my Knees,
" That Heav'n may bless you and your future Bride.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Too gen'rous Fair, Oh! spare your Grief's Profusion;
Show me less Love, be cruel out of Pity;
Tell me you hate me, I shall be less wretched.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I cannot; Oh! then leave me, quickly leave me;
Fly my Contagious Grief. Oh! 'twill infect you.
I merit not your Care, much less your Love.
And yet forgive, and let me Love you still.
As for your Grief, impose it on me, Heav'n!
For I am grown familiar with Affliction.
But live, and think your Death my greatest dread.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Then I must strive to live: But oh! Placentia,
'Twill cost my Love much dearer than to dye.
If one Hour's Absence made me wild with Sorrow,
How shall I live, for ever parted from you,
By Hills and Seas, and the more fatal Cloyster?
How bear the Sun shou'd rise, the Sun shou'd set,
And I ne're blest with my Placentia's sight?
Yet fear not, my Complaints shou'd reach your Cell.
No, not so much as the Tidings of my Death
Shall give you cause to think there liv'd on Earth
So lost a Wretch as I.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Take her away, she heightens his Distraction.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh! stay one moment more, then tear me from my self,
Here let me seal my everlasting Leave.
Farewel, thou Innocent, thou blest Destruction!
Kind Cruelty, sweet Torment of my Soul;
All that's Delight and Pain transcending Thought;
My Soul, my Blessing, and my earthly Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Part them.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh! let me take another parting Look.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Force 'em asunder.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I cannot bearâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hold, stir not, on your Lives.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Hold, impious, sacrilegious Villains, hold!
Pull, hale, drag, cut, part, tear me Limb from Limb,
Yet still I'll holdâ€”she's gone.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Farewel, thou dear unhappy Man, farewel.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Wolves, Tigers, Fiends, you shall not 'scape unpunish'd.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: He'll but obstruct me, if he staysâ€”I'll free him.
My Lord, 'twas needful Cruelty to force you from her.
But I'll yet prove your Friend, and free you instantly.
Go travel when you please; I'll not impose
My Sister on you, tho' your Father wou'd.
This private way you may get out unseen.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Tho' I can't thank you, I accept the offer.
Captain, once more I'll try to see Placentia;
Then I'll aboard your Brigantine again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: My Lord, part of my Men ashore keep close together,
The rest aboard wait for us: All the Slaves
Sit ready at their Oars.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Alas! poor Men!
Tho' they're not half so wretched as my self.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Guards I dismiss you.
sp.stage: [Ex. Fabiano, Captain, and his Attendants one way, and the Guards another way.
sp.l: He's gone, and she's secur'dâ€”so far 'tis wellâ€”
Page, tell Placentia, that Fabiano's here,
And has prevail'd with me to let him see her.
This may decoy her hitherâ€”my Time's short,
Yet I will fetch thee back, and tug with thee,
Thou shifting Fortuneâ€”E're thou part'st from me,
Resolve to leave some of the spoyls I hold;
I will not be left nakedâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hah! deceiv'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Nay, start not back, he's gone for ever now.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: And do you think to keep me here by force?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Yes, force must act, when kinder usage fails:
I'll give you still an hour: But then resolve
To wed me, or appease my am'rous Rage.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Wer't thou as great, as Lawless Pow'r cou'd make thee,
And I as poor as Nature first design'd me,
Know, rather than I'd serve thy horrid pleasures,
I'd Fly to Desarts, to the Land of Sorrow,
Bear with the want of freedom, light and food.
Nay, I wou'd plunge in Seas, and ev'n in Hell,
But that, I know, thou wou'dst torment me there.
Such is my hate, I'll desperately dare,
And, to shun Thee, all other Curses bear.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Then hear thy Doom. Out of meer Spight I love thee,
Love thee with most inveterate bent of mind.
And thus will hate thee worse; yes worse I'll hate thee,
When force has gain'd what thou deny'st my Love.
That which will quench my Flame, shall kindle thine;
Then for the Pleasing Cure to me thou'lt run,
Still close thou'lt follow, but as fast I'll shun:
From wealth, from me, I'll calmly see thee torn,
And leave thee nothing but thy naked scorn.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hear thou, the surer fate attends thy Crimes;
In sudden wealth, as sudden a decay:
Then universal hate, in pressing want;
And, in that want, sickness without Relief.
Thus lingring, thou shalt envy starving beggars;
Shame and Reproach clogging thy heavy hours.
Then, guilty conscience hurrying on despair,
Hang between Heav'n and Earth, as fit for neither;
And none Endeav'ring thy curst life to save,
Dye without Tears or Pray'rs, and want a Grave.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: 'Tis well thou'rt gone, proud Thing. I'm urg'd so far,
I scarce cou'd hold from making good my Threats.
'Tis yet too soon, but if my plot succeeds
Thou shalt be mine, or bear thy share of Ruin.
If I'm left hopeless, hope not to be spar'd.
No, when I fall unpittied, perish Nature;
Dye all that's humane in me but Revenge;
Like a fall'n spright to desperation driv'n,
I'd be more damn'd to keep my Foes from heav'n;
With pow'rful spight I'll all their hopes destroy,
And drag 'em downwards with a dismal Joy.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Morat, and Zemet, who keeps at a distance.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: THe Day's grown old, and almost lost in night:
Work in each Street gives way to soft amusements:
All Nature's business seems now to be Love.
The wind with stronger sighs salutes the Flowers,
Descending Clouds embrace and kiss the Earth.
And, while the Sun on the Sea's bosome Rests,
Th' officious Moon, who winks, with half a face,
Lends a securer light to meeting Lovers.
For now they meet; Th' impatient happy youth
Sees his kind Nymph come tripping or'e the Plain:
They fly, they rush into each others arms,
The Lover's Bless'd and rifles all her Charms.
Thus eager, but less certain, here I come
To seek my better Fate, my lov'd Placentia.
Make haste, O night, extend thy sable Wings!
Let Nature wear a blacker Face than mine,
When the Fair owns her Love, and I my self,
When with kind Rudeness, I force willing Kisses,
Hide, hide Placentia's blushes from my Eyes,
Or with Excess of joy, the bless'd Vincentio dyes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: But are you sure the Ship's at your disposal.

sp.speaker: 1 Bra.
sp.l: The Brigantine is ours, my Lord; we could not
Get one sor any hire; but seiz'd on this with ease.
Most of the men were gone ashore. Besides
The Captain is a new revolted Pyrate,
Who was as glad of us as we of him.
sp.stage: Enter Servants with Lights, which they set upon the Table.
sp.l: Hush! here's the Moor!â€”In half an hour attend me.

sp.speaker: Morat
sp.l: Whisp'ring and Bravoes! sure there's mischief hatching.
For once I'll force my self to seem a Villain,
To sift out, and prevent itâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You're punctual, worthy Moor, but why so thoughtful?

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: I was but thinking
Why men, who know each other to be Cheats,
Shou'd to their prejudice strive to seem honest.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What, do you think I now dissemble with you?

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Why not, my Lord? since I my self dissembled.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: How! you? plain-dealing blunt Morat dissemble?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: We all for Love, Revenge, or Int'rest feign,
And all, for diff'rent ends, seem diff'rent men,
Then shift like Play'rs, and are ourselves again.
Ev'n the most wise, with studied labour, hide,
When flatter'd, Joy; and when exalted, Pride.
Old Maids, if such there be, dissemble youth;
Young Widows, sorrow; Wives and Husbands, truth.
The heir feigns Joy, if his sick friends revive,
Yet almost dyes for grief that they're alive;
The Trader rails at Thieves who Forests range,
Cants, prays, yet cheats, and shakes a whole Exchange.
The Common Jilt, with face and passion feign'd,
Hugs some rich fool, nor leaves him, till he's drain'd.
Dissembling's all Mankind's Prerogative
We know 'tis us'd by all, yet still believe,
And thus are all deceiv'd, and all alike deceive.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I've been deceiv'd indeed. What, wou'd you tempt
Your Convert to relapse?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Come, come, unmask my Lord, I'm bare-fac'd now,
And know you; know me too; I'm left Executor,
And the Will gives your Sisters and Placentia
Most of th' Estate. I've nothing but my Sword;
Command it, and my Pow'r, so I may share
Some of the gain you by my means may reap.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Shall I believe thee true?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Like all mankind, true to my Interest.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Then thou'lt be true to meâ€”
Come to my arms, thou surest, best of friends.
With feeble Oaths we'll not each other bind;
No Tye but Int'rest strongly links mankind.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You love Placentia?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I love no Woman, but I lust for all;
And her above the rest; tho hopeless yet:
But now I've a design, you soon shall knowâ€”
Hark, Music!â€”sure this Serenade's for her;
'Tis giv'n so near her Window; let's put out
The lights; perhaps we may know more.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Placentia! hah! I find I am not proof
Against th'intruding Monster Jealousy.
Out of my heart, thou gnawing envious passion!
Tho look'st so like a Vice, I will not lodge Thee.

div.stage: A Serenading Symphony is heard, as from without. Enter Placentia while 'tis perform'd.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: What wretch has chos'n this night for Serenades?
Alas! my only Charmer's gone for ever,
And with him all the Joys these Notes wou'd summon.
They might as well before Church-windows revel,
And with unheeded Numbers tempt the Dead.
Yet have my hopeless wishes drawn me hither,
Where I unseen may best inform my self,
Whether, as I suspect, these are not this Musicians.
Perhaps he's not gone yet, but stays to free me.
Time was I shou â€¢ d have trembl'd thus alone,
But Grief and Fear itself have made me bold.
sp.stage: Enter Fabiano, Captain, a Servant, with a dark Lanthorn.
sp.l: Ha! who are these?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: She's here; fear not, my Soul. 'Tis your adorer.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Stir not yet.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Take this, thou friendly guide, with my best Thanks,
And watch to let us out.

div.stage: Gives the Servant Money. Ex. Servant.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! I am all surprize. Why wou'd you venture thus?
Why, with this Musick? Is't to punish me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Think not those accents meant to move the Soul.
Oh! lovely Maid, more Musick's in your name;
They're but the mournful Prelude to my Dirge;
And serve t'amuse observing Spyes one way,
That we more safely may escape another:
For I am come once more to see and free you,
Then go, where my despair shall neer torment you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh I must share your grief where e're you go;
You never can be absent from my heart.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: I hope, I dream.
Is this the love I blest my self withal!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Sighs stop my words.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: And Tears obstruct my sight.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Oh! if you lov'd!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I love you but too well,
For my Soul's quiet, dear unhappy man.

sp.speaker: Morat,
sp.l: Oh cursed sound! he's lov'd! he's but too happy.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Go prosecute your generous Design,
See foreign Lands, and visit distant Courts!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Since you will have me go, I will Placentia:
But not to Courts. No, I will find some Desart:
There will I linger out a wretched Being,
Till grief that nurse of Sighs, can yield no more,
And with your name upon my Lips, I dye.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Alas, my Wishes contradict themselves;
I wish you'd lov'd me still, I wish you wou'd forget me.
Yet love me, love me still, where e're you go.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Racks, Wheels, and Vultures!â€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Stay, but one moment, I will fetch some Jewels;
" To pay my Portion to the Monastry,
" Then I'll fly thither under your conduct,
For there's no safety here, now brave Vincentio's Dead.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Oh! that he were!â€”(aside.) I can forbear no longer.
Who are you there, that with false Lights and Vows
Seek to dishonor noble families,
By ravishing young Virgins from their Houses?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Whoe're thou art, I justly fling the lye back in thy face.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Our quarrel's just o' both sides, if 't be so:
Then let not odds on mine e're make it less.
How many are you arm'd?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: We're only two, yet dare defie you all;
Tho, if the Moon's faint light deceives me not, you're three.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That shall not be; Ricardo, now stand by. Draw, Zemetâ–ª

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No, I'll get lightsâ€”I hope they'll rid me of a Rival.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Whoe're thou art, tho thy Reproach was base,
Yet this proceeding's noble. Wou'd we had
The Sun to light us to each other's face. I wou'd see thine
Let's to some fitter place to sight this quarrel,
For which I know no motive but thy Rudeness.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes, there are many; but my face wou'd show
By light but little otherwise than now.
I am the Moor, deceas'd Vincentio's friend.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I ever lov'd him;
And, for his sake, I wou'd not kill thee, Moor.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: But he wou'd thee, if he were in my place,
For stealing thus from him Placentia's love.
But I'll revenge at once his wrongs and mine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Were he alive. I'd not invade his right;
And as for thee, how canst thou say I wrong'd thee?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh! ye immortal Pow'rs! What, have I got
A talking syllogistick Enemy?
And for a prize great as Placentia's heart?
Know, whosoe're thou art, I love Placentia.
Will that yet rouse thy Courage?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hah! Thou love her!
Vile Black! I'll free her from that shame, or dye.

div.stage: Morat fights Fabiano, the Capt. fights Zemet, and disarms him out of sight, then (to joyn with Fabiano,) he Re-enters, supporting hims â€¢ elf on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Zem.
sp.l: Disarm'd! Curst Chance! Help! Help!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Unlucky Wound! he has hurt me in the Thigh,
And now I'm useless.

div.stage: Enter Placentia, who offers to step between them.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! hold! or know you kill a harmless Maid.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Madam, retire.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Leave us a while, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No, here I'll take my death, or hinder yours.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Oh! fly! while this Moor lives, I cannot free you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ah! why so cruel, Moor!

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: I love and will not lose you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: The name of love is posion'd on thy Tongue.
Oh! sully not my Virtue with thy passion.
Can you now think me worth your care, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Heav'n can receive no spots from Blasphemy;
But, spight of that, the pious pay their duty,
And mine's to dye or free you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! stay! hold! if you love your selves or me,
Who first desists, I'll think the truest lover.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Must I not punish him?

div.stage: She suddenly interposes and holds Fabiano.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Yes in my armsâ€”Thus punish him more safely.
Now, Moor, if thou woud'st kill him, kill me too.

div.stage: Enter Ricardo, Zemet, and Servantss with lights.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Fabiano!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: How does my worthy friend?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh! never worse.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Where are you wounded, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh! at the heartâ€”by killing jealousy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Madam, till morning I must leave you here,
And then I'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh that's too long, where honour is unsafe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Let him protect you there, if I am grown
So fear'd a Ravisher.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Madam, we will: my wounded friend wants help,
The Moor is brave, and thus we must be safe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Zemet, While I retire, stay and observe 'em.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: O do not fear me, Madam: what I threatn'd
Is far from my intent, 'twas but to fright you
Into complying. I adore your virtue.
Oh pardon me, be blest, and make me so.

div.stage: Enter Laura, with her two Children led by Servants.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hah!

div.stage: They start and look amazedly at each other.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Both, if you stay.
You found me begging here a reconcilement
Of this fair Enemy, who's wedded to a Cloyster;
But I'll withdraw with you, to know what fit
Usurps your patience, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, learn that here.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh hold! retire, or we're undone.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, perjur'd man. All here shall known my wrongs.
Despair disclaims Reserves: 'tis as I fear'd;
Impatient Creditors drive me from home,
Just now my goods were seiz'd, and here thy heart.
All, all, I find, is lostâ–ª of what the fondness
Of my late Husband left me when he dy'd,
I've nothing now, but these his helpless Infants;
These Innocents, depriv'd like their poor Mother,
Ev'n of a place to lay their little heads.

sp.speaker: 1 Child.
sp.l: Oh sad! have we then ne'r another home?
I'm hungry, cold, and tir'd, indeed I am.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh wretched Children, but more wretched Mother!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: This Scene adds grief to grief, yet tempts to stay:

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I share your sorrows, Madam: Let's withdraw,
You may expect to find a friend in me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: A friend! how cold, how unlike one he talks!
And looks, as if I were his Wife already.
I'm lost, he's false! I saw it. This confirms it.
I can no longer doubt the dreadful truth.
But if Revengeâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I dare no longer stay.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Stay, thou invader of my right.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hold, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Stay, I'm all patience yet!
Let me peruse you, Madamâ€”
Thou vulgar thing, thou Face mean as thy Birth,
How durst thou tempt the Creature of my Love?
I'm now convinc'd that nothing but a Philtre
Cou'd thus divert his choice from me to thee.
But wer't thou Beauty's Queen, thy charms are vain,
I'd blast them all, my conquest to maintain.
Dare but to hope my slave to disengage,
Not heav'n it self shall shield thee from my Rage.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If Don Ricardo's yours, pray keep him, Madam.
I cou'd ev'n hate my self for pleasing him;
Then think not I'll e're court his odious Love,
Sooner shall freedom doat on Tyranny,
Sooner will I be perjur'd, or he true.

div.stage: [Ex. Plac. led by Fabiano. Zem. after 'em

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: By her Disdain, it shou'd be so.â€”Just Powers!
Shou'd he shun me, to doat on one who shuns him,
'Twou'd be Revenge, yet heighten my Disgrace.
Am I then fallen so low to seek him whom she scorns?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I still am trueâ€”But hear me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, thou can'st only be thy self, and false.
I've heard too much, I'm cur'd at once and loath thee.
I thought not, I so tamely cou'd have born
Thy change; but 'tis so poor, I scorn thee now.
Raise my fortunes
High as they stood, our contract shall be void.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Can you mean this?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Witness it, all that hear me!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Then be it so.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Do you consent?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: First perish she, thou, I and all the World.
Persidious Fool! cou'd'st thou presume to think
I'd give thee leave to live and be another's?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I was a fool,â€”for I believ'd a Woman!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And I a greater, I believ'd a Manâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What shall I do? out of meer pity I must use her ill.
Curst be your Love, and your assuming Pride,
Still thus Vexatious, but most curst your Cunning!
Thus do too many of your Sex deceive us;
For they can feign and lye and weep at will.â€”
Reserv'dness is a Bawd to their stol'n pleasures.
For, as some wear fine Cloaths with empty purses,
They 've but the dress of virtue, not the substance.
Their modesty's as thin, as are their Veils,
Worn alike ev'ry where, but in their Chambers.
Their Reason is a Slave to their wild Passions,
Their honesty to the Desires of Men,
And their best vertue's damn'd Hypocrisyâ–ª

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And what's your Sexe's who thus rail at ours,
To hide your worse dissembling, which all ours
Is but to Counterplot; while all the faults,
For which you blame us, are still caus'd by you?
You, who all promise, and who all betray;
Who use your stronger sense to ruin our weakness:
And take a greater freedom to be bad,
Nay, boast ev'n of more vice than you can act;
Force us to feign, and live recluse like Slaves,
Yet damn us for a slip, of which you glory.
You, proud, deluding, treach'rous Tyrantâ€”Men:
Your very Heroes are but bold Destroyers,
Your good Companions are but Libertines,
And your fond Lovers but designing Traytors.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I find 'tis vain to think t'outrail a Woman.
I must try softer means.
Trust me, were both undone, if you rave on;
But if you're calm, I'll double your Estate.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Cruel, how durst thou thus affront my Love?
What did I ever wish for, but thy heart?
Did I desire thy wealth? Did I not give thee
All I possest and beggar these young wretches,
Whose sight now fills my drooping Soul with Grief,
And sinks my spirits to the lowest ebb;
For, with our Wealth, our Spirits sink, I find.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh check that Loveâ€”You know not what you ask.
Whate're I seem, I scorn t' undo you more.
I amâ€”Oh! I shall say too much! I swear,
The dismal truth was on my lipsâ€”Farewelâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Stay! Oh! I dye with shame, but cannot leave him.
Heav'ns, is this he who swore eternal truth!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Do, rail on, curse me, hate me, scorn me, spurn me,
That I may dare to wrong you, or we're ruin'd!
Heav'n knows 'tis fate, more than my falsehood, parts usâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh racks! oh pangs! oh that we could but deal
With love, when slighted, as we can with friendship,
Part company, and love and friendship too.
But 'twill not beâ€”I burst with grief and rage.
Must I bear this? Is there no way to ease?
My Rivalâ€”I'll find her out, and give her instant death.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hold Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Let me go.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You must not.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Prevented! and by thee? Oh my heart breaks!
My Rage works inwardsâ€”help; I faintâ€”I dye!

div.stage: Swoons in her Womens arms, and is laid in an Arm-Chair.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Oh help my Lady!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Run to my Closet! I've rich Cordials thereâ€”
By heavens I pity her!
Yes, from my Soul I do. Her Charms, her Love
Deserve a better fate! Oh! I cou'd kill my self,
My most unhappy fickle self! but hold!
Wou'd that relieve her? No: Then live, Ricardo,
Live to supply her wants out of Placentia's fortuneâ–ª
But how? while Laura lives, she'll still obstruct thee.
" Oh! whither am I driv'n? Thoughts not so far!
" But if she lives we're ruin'd both! a dreadful truth!
" I feel a strange Remorse.
Stay, Life's to her a greater pain than Death.
Then let her dyeâ€”
" Down checking scruples. Let me tell my Soul
" 'Tis a kind act, and necessary mischief.
sp.stage: Re-enter Servant with a Case of Bottles, Ri. opens it, takes out one, and causes some drops to be pour'd into Laura's mouth.
sp.l: Few drops of this will soon restore her sencesâ€”
And in few hours give her eternal rest.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: How your hand shakes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Alas! I'm much concern'd for her, poor Ladyâ€”
See, she revives.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: More cruelly to dye.
For, to the wretched, Life's a punishment,
And most to me, lost, hopeless, yet still loving.
Oh women, women, boast your pow'r no more.
How soon our pride is humbled! first we triumph,
But oh 'tis only with more weight to feel
Th' insulting scorn of our Rebellious Slaves.
Weep, Laura weep! Think how with this false Charmer
(Checking thy native haughtiness of Soul)
Thou cou'dst have liv'd an humble Cottage mate,
A pattern to all Wives. Yet now he slights thee;
Tho ruin'd for his sake, and unpossest.
Oh let me rave, be mad, tear, tear my hair,
My face, my eyes, curse their weak Charms,
Groan on the ground, and grovel till at last
It hides me in a Grave.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, rise.
There's an apartment ready to receive you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Away!â€”Think not I'll stay in this ungrateful Houseâ–ª
No, let me lye expos'd to the bleak Air,
On the cold pavement, in some lonesome street;
A Lodging fit for my forlorn condition;
While my poor Children, freezing, tir'd, half famisht,
With tears and moans pierce the most cruel hearts,
And with cold scraps feed miserable life.
Oh dismal, dismal thought! But 'twill not long torment me:
I shall run mad, I hope. Yet then, I fear,
As on my Straw I rave, a doleful spectacle,
Still with a sigh to all my Sex I'll cry,
Thus, thus, poor Laura fares for being true.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! how this shakes my Soul! she shall not dye.
Run, fetch Physiciansâ€”But hold, I'm mad too.
How will that help her?â€”Gently raise her up,
Then lead her hence to rest.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: It must be to the Grave then. Wou'd it were,
So my curst Rival were but there with me!
Oh how the thoughts of her inflame my Soul!
May a wrong'd woman's Curses soon o'retake her,
Wrinkles, Deformity, Desires, and Scorn,
Detracting blast her fame, worst plagues her Charms,
Eternal Disappointments, Grief, Disquiet,
Confusion Shame, and Misery like mine
Pursue her, and the cause of my Despair.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: How my Soul's rackt; shame combating with pity!
Methinks I see her still, and the Bane's workingâ€”
I feel her Pangs, I hear her Groansâ€”Oh horror!

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.l: My Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: It shall not be; I'll save her, tho I perishâ€”

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord! He's lost in thought.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: But will that ease her?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hah!â€”

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I've brought the Captain of the Ship: our friends
Wait with his men without.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I thank thee, Hell! thou hast determin'd me.
Plate, Money, Jewels, and the chief, the Women,
This very night shall all be shipt for Afric.
Come, let's make all things ready for our flight;
Then in Placentia's Lodgings seize Fabiano;
He'll be an Hostage for our future Pardon,
Oh Laura!â€”But I cannot help thy Fall.
Necessity makes. Villains of us all.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: OH haste, let's fly, my Lord!â€”Ricardo's Threats,
His busie gloomy Looks, his odd Expressions,
That Lady's wrongs, her Rage, and all things here,
Must have convinc'd you, 'tis unsafe to stay.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But oh my Captain?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: The danger cannot reach him.

div.stage: Enter three Bravoes, who surprize Fab. take his Sword, throw it by, and bind him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ha! Villains! by whose orders am I seiz'd?

sp.speaker: 1 Bra.
sp.l: By Don Ricardo's hedesigns no hurt:
As for you, Madam, you must now deliver
Your Money, Plate, and Jewels; else we've orders
To take 'em all by force.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Assist me then, Despair!
If there's no Remedy, go with me yonder;
You'll find much more than e're your hearts cou'd wish:

sp.speaker: 1 Bra.
sp.l: Search ev'ry where, while I attend Ricardo.

div.stage: Two of the Bravoes run to the place pointed to 'em by Placentia, she steps out after 'em, locks a door, and re-enters immediately.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: By happy Chance I've lockt the Villains in,
While eagerly they rush'd to seize their Preyâ€”
I must unbind you, but I tremble so,
I scarce have pow'r to do it.

div.stage: Enter Ricardo hastily, with a Dagger in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hold!

sp.speaker: Pla. and Fa.
sp.l: Hah!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Attempt to free him, and he dyes.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Thus Robbers steal our wealth, then leave us bound.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You're robb'd of nothing since she'd be a Nun;
Neither shall you be left, but go with us.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: She shall not go.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Villain, I will not go;
And rather wou'd be wedded to the Plague.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! how that blush of Rage, that sullen Grace,
That scornful smile, now blended with a frown,
That soft Emotion, and that wild of Beauty
Fire my hot blood! It mantles, bubbles, boyls!
My full Veins swell, and the revulsive Red
Whirls flushing o're my face. Oh I'm all transport!
I must, I will be blest, The coy Placentia,
Since she'll not be my Wife, shall be my Mistress.
Come, quickly yield! for I'll this very moment.
Secure my bliss, lest my design shou'd fail.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: If thou'rt a man, unbind and kill me first.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Rave on, and like the damn'd now feel a hell,
To see me seize the Heav'n of love by force.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh save me, heav'n! Ricardo, think of heav'n.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hold! Is the man lost in the lustful Brute?
Thou lookst a man, then bear thee now like one,

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: So I intendâ€”Come, with me, or I'll force you.

div.stage: Pulls Pla. while Fabiano is striving privately to unbind himself.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Can fruit while immature indulge the Taste?
Oh! stay! do not prophane th' unyielding Tree;
Kind usage and necessity at last
May ripen crabbed hate to gen'rous Love.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I scorn the fruit which of itself do's fall,
I love a pleasure I must struggle for.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your appetite's deprav'd, your Love distemper'd.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: If 'tis deprav'd, and t'other a disease,
Then, sweet or sowr, the Physick must be taken;
Besides, Resistance will enhaunce the blessing;
Insatiate in the Riot of my Joys,
I'll bribe, or teach, or force you to be pleas'd.
I'll grasp the trembling, panting, struggling Maid,
Grac'd with variety of new disorder;
Her dress, her tresses loose, and in her face
Roses, and Lillies in alternate chase.
I'll see her beg, and beg, to be deny'd,
With heaving breasts, soft looks, short balmy Sighs,
Kind broken words, and trickling pearly Tears,
While my proud Rival by, sees, rages, and despairs.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Racks, Wheels, and Fires, must I be still restrain'd!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Comply!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I must not.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Marry me then.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hope.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I hate long Siegesâ€”'Tis Soldier-like to Storm.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But not to storm weak woman! Oh! forbear!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll stab thee then.

div.stage: [In a threatning posture, then suddenly embraces her:

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I'll thank you.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: When 'tis doneâ€”thou charming stubborn Folly.
Thou Foe to thy own Pleasureâ€”what still foolish?â€”
Sure I can grapple with you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh Heav'n! Crush, crush us both with Thunder! oh! my Lord!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Curst Sight! Death to my Eyes! Hell to my Soul!
I cannot bear it
Blast, Thunder, striek, burn, tear me or my bands!â€”
Ha!â€”Now, Fate, I half forgive theeâ€”
sp.stage: Rises, having freed his Legs, comes up to Ricardo.
sp.l: Turn, Monster!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Away! fly instant Fate! 'tis in my hand.
" Thou mayst more safely tempt the greedy Lyon,
" When with contracted Paws he grumbles o're his prey.
Be gone! I never threaten twice.
Villain, stab, or desist.

div.stage: Pushes Ric. roughly. Offers to stab him. Pla. steps between.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Fond, rash fool, take thy wish!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hah! What means Placentia?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: To rob you of that blow; I want it most.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Restraint, your danger, check, distract, unman meâ€”
Oh! my Placentia! Oh Ricardo spare her!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! my Fabiano! Oh Ricardo, spare him!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Too long I've trifl'dâ€”stand out of Death's way.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No, strike, strike thro my Heart! still thus I'll stand,
Between the dear unhappy Man and Fate.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: The dearer he's, the sooner he shall dye.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! take the wealth I now was leaving! kill me!
" Alas my Death will mend my wretched state,
" And I, instead of burying my self living
" Within the lonesom Walls of some poor Cloyster,
" Will lye more quiet in the silent Grave,
" Forgot among the solitary Tombs.
But on my knees, which fear has scarce left able
To bear my Trembling body, by your Love,
By the remaining Tears of this sad day,
By your best hopes, and by your future safety,
Let me adjure you, spare him, spare my honour,
Nor act a Crime you'd wish undone too late.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Down Stubborn Heart! bend knees!
A Goddess kneels; but see a greater wonder,
Ricardo! see thy Rival at thy Feet!
Not to beg life! ah no! I wish to dye:
Spare her! oh spare her! Let my blood attone.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Something I feel like Pity; but I'll hide itâ€”
Or yield, or wed me now, or both shall dye.
sp.stage: To Pla. who holds him by the arm.
sp.l: Let go your holdâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh do no drag me thus!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Bound as I am, I'll strive to snatch thy Dagger.

div.stage: Fa. with both his hands seizes Ricardo's Dagger. They struggle. Ri. falls. She gets his Sword, and points it to his breast.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Hah!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Now, Villain, tremble! Stir, and thou dy'st.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh do not kill meâ€”I'm not fit to dyeâ€”

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Nor ever wilt; therefore unfit to live:
" What shou'dst thou fear, thou'rt all a Devil already.
" Thy lowest fall can be but into Hell.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh, that's uncharitable!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Then that's like thee:
" Infection's busie where you breathe! Dyeâ€”

div.stage: Pla. offers to kill Ri. Fa. hinders her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: " Hold, dear Placentia, let me interpose:
" I'll shield him, but to punish him my self.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " No, his Sword must let out his tainted blood.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Let not blood stain your Innocence.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " A Monster's blood ne'r stains the hand that sheds it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Can a Virgin do this?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " A Virgin wrong'd can more.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " 'Tis not her office to be cruel.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " But 'tis ev'ry one's office to do justice.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh! you are pious, and you must forgive.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Now you can preach that pity you deny'd.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh! 'twas excess of Love that urg'd my Crime.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Thou never hadst that goodness as to love.
Dye, Virtue strikes, not I.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hold, Madam, free my hands; I'll kill him then.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why venture twice your life against a Villain?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What can I have to lose, when you are lost?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: aside. I hate this lingringâ€”Thus I'll scape or dye.

div.stage: Starts up suddenly, and runs out.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ha! now he's scap'd, and 'tis our turn to fear.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I'll fly for help, unbind me.

div.stage: Enter Morella, Melinda, and two of their women.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: We've heard a dismal noiseâ€”Fabiano bound!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: 'Tis now no time to talk; secure that door.
sp.stage: They bar the doors on the side where Ri. came out.
sp.l: Theft, Rape and Murder are at handâ€”
Some of you, ring the Bell, it may bring help.

div.stage: They unbind Fabiano, who takes up the Sword.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Quick, call the Captain: now his wound is bound,
Tho lame, he may assist.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: without. Open the door.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: No, not to Thieves and Ravishers.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: without. We'll break 'em open then.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Heaven send us succour first.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I fear it much.

div.stage: Enter Captain, supporting himself on a stick.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why, then I can but dye for you, Placentia.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Talk not of dying, Sir, but of defence.
Let's keep close by the passage,
There we shall better make our party good.

div.stage: The door is burst open, the Women shriek.
Enter Ricardo, Bravoes, Sailers and Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Fall on!

div.stage: Ri. and the Bravoes fight, Fa. and the Capt. who give way by degrees, till the Lieutenant finding his Capt. there, falls on the Bravoes, and with the help of the Sailors disarms them and Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Our Captain's here! fall on the Rogues.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My men are here, beyond my expectation.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Betray'd by cursed Pyrates!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Lieutenant, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Our Brigantine, Sir, was o're-pow'r'd by Villains;
