So many of our men being on shore.
They came upon us so at unawares,
There was no other help but joyning with them.
I told them I was a revolted Pyrate,
Who would be glad of such good company;
And thus, since that, I've trac'd them in their mischiefs,
Being resolv'd to seize 'em, when my men
Were got together, as they are now.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Where is the Moor?

sp.speaker: Lieu
sp.l: We cannot find him yet.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Bind all the Villains, and confine Ricardo.

div.stage: Enter Don Vincentio undisguis'd, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Forbear, presumptuous Lord!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: How! Don Vincentio living!

sp.speaker: Mol. and Mar.
sp.l: Hah! 'tis my Brother's Ghost!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Risen from the Grave;

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why d' you all shun me? But perhaps you ought.
Yet, tho much chang'd, I am Vincentio still.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Alive! oh grant it heav'n.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You've been impos'd upon, I find.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh my dear Brother, how I mourn'd for you!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Come I'll believe he lives, tho 'twere a Dream,
" That I may know one joyful Moment more.

div.stage: [The Ladies and Ri. run to embrace him, he makes 'em sign to forbear.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Spare Compliments! It is your love I'd have;
When I am sure of that, the rest is needless.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: My Lord, your Ear a moment.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: I find, there have been strange disorders here.
Placentia, as for you, I hear you're grown
An absolute disposer of your self.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ah can your Soul more than your face be chang'd!
You did not use to meet our joys this way.
Oh! my best Lord! upon my knees I beg
That Calumny may not possess your Soul!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How am I chang'd indeed; I can stand by,
And see Placentia kneel. Oh! jealousy,
Thou hast perverted all my noble nature:
Thou drov'st out flatt'ring hope when most secure,
And all my Gen'rous passions follow'd it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do's it become Placentia thus to kneel, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: If you dislike her low Condition, raise her!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: So, I can, Sir, and to as high a pitch
As yours, tho mounted thus in all its pride.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: My Lord, you've in my absence stoln a Jewel
I priz'd above my life, my very being.
Restore it me again on your Sword's point;
And by the Grove where I kill'd rash Don John.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: to him.] I'll meet you; say no moreâ€”Rise, noble Maid.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No, I will grow to Earth, except my Lord
Turns merciful again, and hears me speak!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: aside. Hopes of Revenge have beat out jealousy,
And I'm my self againâ€”Ah lovely Maid,
To what but Heav'n shou'd so much Beauty kneel?
Oh! I was mad, Placentia! quickly rise,
Or I shall sink into the Earth for shame:
His words made no impression on my Mind.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: My Lord, pray keep your Temper, nor suspect me;
For I have proofs, I wish the Moor were here!
He first betray'd their ill designs to me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why then, ye equal judges, hear him speak!
I am the Moorâ€”do you start, base Traducer?
But thou'rt below my Thoughts? 'Tis you, Placentia,
I now must chide.
" Why, Cruel fair,
" Why will you thus shut out your lovely self
" From all the World? I prize no other Wealth,
" And wou'd you, wou'd you steal your self from him
" Who without you must dye? for oh Placentia,
" None can divide the Body from the Soul.
" Yet make that Body live.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Alas! Vows firm as fate for ever part us.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: " Yet stay, That I may see you shine at Court.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " Ah no! my Lord, vertue shines best in Cloysters.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: " But oh! if you're resolv'd to live recluse,
" And make your fond Vincentio miserable,
" Why must another offer you to Heav'n?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: " You shall dispose of me,
My Lord, my heart
Is by a secret charm bound to Fabiano,
But yet, its Duty must be wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Oh! break that cursed charm, or else deny
All thoughts that prompt a friendship or respect.
Respect was welcome from you, when I thought
None had a stronger Tye upon your Soul.
But that respectâ–ª is now below contempt.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh! tho I love himâ€”

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Oh unspeak those words.
Ten thousand Vipers stung me at the sound;
Ten thousand thoughts, all wild, all black, all dismal,
Work my mad Brain. Oh, say you love him not.
You weepâ€”you are dumbâ€”you will not? Cruel Maid!
Teach me, yet Pow'rs to move herâ€”Oh I wou'd invoke
Men, Angels, Friends, to wrest him from her heart:
But 'twill be vain: how long have I not su'd?
Hours, Days, Months, Years, are past; yet still she's Marble.
I'll dye thenâ€”yes; but first my Rival shall.
I'm ripe for ruin, like some batter'd wall,
But haughty Foe, I'll crush thee with my fall.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Kill me, I'll thank you; for I'm hopeless too.
But live, my Lord, and think me not your foe.
Nothing but barbarous wrong done to Placentia
Cou'd make me draw my Sword against my friend.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Must I be wicked e're I can be eas'd?
Take, take your friendship back. Oh why am I thus curst.
My Brother a base wretch, my Friend my Rival,
And what's yet worse, a Rival lov'd! Oh Tortures!
But what most racks my Soul, this very evening
I thought my self the happy'st man on earth.
From such a hope, in full career to bliss,
Thus to be hurried down a precipice
To dash on deep despair! It kills my reason,
Confounds my Brains, my Heart, and tears my very Soul.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Compose his mind, good Heav'n!

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Rise, my dear Brother.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Oh why will you lye thus?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Oh why indeed indeed! my sword, my sword shou'd end me and my pain.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hold! are you mad?
sp.stage: [Takes his Sword from him, and others hold him.
sp.l: Let Reason end 'em, and preserve your Life.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Away; Life's my worst foe, and you the next;
Think not t'impose it on me. Reason's self,
Nay Patience, says my ills are past her cure.
Oh harship! I'm ev'n deny'd the priviledge of dying.
Then hear, thou heav'n! why sleeps thy thunder? end me!
Delay not thus my wisht for Dissolution.
Oh rid me of Intolerable Life.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Forgive your Friends, and live my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin
sp.l: My Friends! wou'd you be thought my Friend?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes, from my Soul.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Then dare be such, and rid me now of Life.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Wou'd that be like a Friend? Reflect, my Lord:
Exert your Soul, and bear like your great self.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Will you not kill me then?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Were ev'ry door to ease shut up but Death,
Unwillingly I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: There's no other.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Then I must be cruelly kind.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: My Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Madam forbear? Let one friend ease another.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well said?
Come, take your Sword my Friend, and lay its point close to my Breast?
That when I do you the same hated Office,
We both may fall at once.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What, both! forbid it friendship!
I dare not buy my ease at your Life's Cost.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: See, whither passion hurried you, my Lord!
Were wilful Death an ease, shou'd you deny it him
That gives it you? for I too am most wretched.
But Life's the Gift of Heav'n, and we must wait
Till heav'n commands it back, to gain a better.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Oh! you have touch'd my Soul! Come to my Arms!
I'm reconcil'd to wretchedness, to Life,
Nay, ev'n to you: Tho Rivals we'll agree:
Let's all three joyn as partners in affliction.
Till heav'n be mov'd, while nature mourns to find
Three hearts so wretched, yet so truly kind.

sp.speaker: Zem.
sp.l: My Ld, Don Ferdinand, with guards was forcing Entrance,
But, hearing you're return'd, wou'd only kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: My Lord conceal me, lest I be detain'd.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: to Fab. Retire into that Roomâ–ª Go bring him in.

div.stage: Enter Don Ferdinand, with Zemet with him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Welcome, my Lord, to Portugal, that mourn'd
The brave Vincentio's loss! The King himself
Has worn a noble sorrow for your Death;
And doubtless will rejoyce, to see you contradict
That most unwelcome news.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I must employ my Friends, my Lord, for a new pardon,
'Twas I that caus'd the Rumour to be spread;
But 'twas to save a Brother.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He's no Brother.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: My Lord, he's but an ill one, I confess:
Yet, nature still will work.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll say no more, till I have got your promise, of one thing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Name it, my Lord; a gift that you can ask
Must needs be too well plac'd to be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I had a Son, and hope once more to have him,
If this fair Lady will restore him to me,
Once I despis'd her, but admire her now.
I ask her for his Wife, my Lord, that's all.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: All!â€”ask me my Lord, to rip my breast my self,
And give you thence my heart. Ask any thing,
Rather than ask Placentia for your Son.
She must be mine, or no man's in the World.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Lord, she is your Sister.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Hah! my Sister.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Nay then 'tis time to fly: These perjur'd Monks,
Tho he's not dead have made the secret known.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lay hold on him!â€”
This Villain, shall no longer be your plague.

sp.speaker: 1. Monk.
sp.l: No, he's a peasants Son, and she your Sister.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Can Heav'n and Earth conspire to make me wretched?
Sister, that word ne're sounded ill till now.
Sister brings in't eternal separation.
Fathers, you shou'd be Messengers of joy.

sp.speaker: 1. Monk.
sp.l: I hope, My Lord, we shall, if you'll but hear.

sp.speaker: Vin
sp.l: Let me hear any thing but Sister from you.
That fatal sound will murther me at once;
I dare not understand you.
But since I'm doom'd to hear some dreadful story;
'Tis fit I shou'd possess my Soul with Thoughts
Of the most dismal kind!â€”I need not study.
Placentia Loves anotherâ€”That's enough.
Alas! what Racks, what tortures can be worse!
Now tell the restâ€”yet on the Ground I'll lye
Lest I drop down, when she is prov'd my Sister.'
There, wretched Lover, measure out thy Grave.
Now strike the blow that must cut off all hopes.

sp.speaker: 1. Monk.
sp.l: Read that, my Lord! It is a declaration
Under his Parents hands.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: This is enoughâ€”Placentia is my Sister. Oh! my heart!
Turn, turn thy self about, that I may ask
Why this was done?

sp.speaker: 1 Monk.
sp.l: My Lord, you've heard your sickly Infancy
Gave but a doubtful promise of your Life.
This made your Father wish another Son.
But Daughters still deceiv'd him. Now your Mother
Then big with Child, had heard him rashly say,
If that too prov'd a Daughter, he should wish
She never had been his.
This made such an impression on her mind,
That to preserve his Love, he being absent,
Seeing it prov'd a Girl, she chang'd the Child.
This fault her youth committed, and her age repented.
So she with us deposited this Trust,
To be reveal'd, if you dy'd without Issue.
If not, to be kept secret. But just heav'n
Has brought the secret out before its time.
Yet with no breach of trust on our-side neither,
Since we believ'd you dead, when we reveal'd it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Have I not patience, fathers, thus to hear
Such killing news, yet lye here without raving?
But I'll do something too.

div.stage: [starts up and Exit. Monks and Servantâ–ª after him.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Look to my Lord!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Alas! he's much disturb'dâ€”As for these Villains,
To dungeons with them. But for this mock-Lordâ€”
Degrade him first. Strip of this rich garb,
Then Cloath him as befits his state and Birth.
That thus my Lord may see him dragg'd to prison.

sp.speaker: Morel.
sp.l: Oh Sister; 'tis more joy to find you thus,
Than 'tis to lose that wretch.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: This doubles the delight I took in Friendship,
But my Love for you was so great before, it cannot now encrease.

div.stage: Re-enter Ricardo, in an old Gown with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Now, Fortune, Nature,
I owe you nothing but a wretched Being.
Take back the thankless gift, and then we're even,
" Nor rack my Soul with dread of endless Flames.
There's Hell enough on Earth in guilty minds.
" To lose at once the heav'n of Love and Greatness,
" Then be condemn'd to Life, or dye a branded Villain!
" Curst Thought! a branded Villain. Ha! I feel
" A warmth new to my heart, thaw the hard lump,
" And shake my shudd'ring frame.
Oh my past Life, thou mak'st me doubt the future.
Alas, I dare not hope I may repentâ–ª

sp.speaker: Lauraâ–ª
sp.l: Oh run, for pities sake! she is poyson'd.
Get Antidotes! But tell her not, I did it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Run, help the Lady.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! lead me from her Sight, to Chains and Galleys,
To toyl, to shame, to want, to pinching cold,
To scorching heat, to stripes, to worse Remorse,
And ever-new variety of Woes.
All, all these pains are slight, to those I bear,
Struggling for hope with horror and despair.
Stay! Poys'ner Fiend,! take this and this.

div.stage: (Exit Ricardo bloody, Guarded by the Lieutenant, &c.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Hold, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: More horrors yet! oh let's avoid that Sight.

div.stage: Ex. Pla. with Fer. Morel. and Mel.
Enter Laura and Richardo. She holds a Dagger in her hand, and drops it as she struggles with the Servants.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why do you hold me? let me end that Monster!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Strike, injur'd Goodness; strike again; I'll thank you.
" Compleat the work of Death, that moves too slow.
" But oh! first hear me, take some Antidote.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Must I be held, and punisht with his sight?
" Free me, or take him hence, for horror shakes me
Ev'n at the thoughts that he's of humane form.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh stay; look on the most undone of Creatures,
A Devil in guilt, but a repenting Devil.
Oh! cou'd but heav'n and you forgive.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Avantâ€”Devils can't repent, nor be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: But ev'n the worst of Men, thus prostrate trembling,
Not daring to look up, near death, will sigh to heav'n.
" Oh! you're so much its likeness,
" Sure its best attribute, Divine forgiveness
" May yet be show'r'd ev'n on a wretch like me.
" A Wretch, more, more than a wretch, there's not a name
" That can express my miserable state.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Let go my Robes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh never, never,
The drowning wretch cannot forego his hold;
That lost, I sink for ever.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: " I'd sink with thee, that thou might'st sink yet lower.
" Think on my wrongs, thou Fiend, thy breach of Vows,
" Ingratitude, that ev'n thy Sex must startle,
" Poyson thy kind return for all my wealth,
" For all my Love, and what cries most for Vengeance,
" Those poor young Orphans! Oh my ruin'd Children.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh! take some Antidote!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, I wou'd dye: what shou'd I live for now?
see behind me nothing left in Life
â€¢ ut misery, terrible misery.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh Lauraâ€”

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Wil't thou still plague me? Dye, and let me dye.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh! had you heard me, but an hour ago,
" We might have liv'd. Alas you little know
" What's now divulg'd; I'm not Vincentio's Brother.
Death to a wretch like me has lost its horror;
Death shou'd have snatch'd me in my fancy'd greatness;
But now my base original, my Crimes,
My shame call for severer punishments.
The Rack shou'd stretch my Limbs, and show me death in view,
Then pull the blessing back, that I might long be tortur'd.
Then let me starve with those poor helpless Orphans,
Whom I have robb'd of the support their dying Father left.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: " Oh now thou'st touch'd my Soul,
" And laid my Crimes as well as thine in view.
" I, I, was left entrusted with the Care.
" How shall I meet my Husbands shade? methinks
" I see his angry Ghost! he frownsâ€”oh hide me.
" Forgive, blest soul; forgive a poor deluded Woman!â€”
" But oh! my Children, how can you forgive me?â€”
" Yet once more let me see 'emâ€”stay; I dare not,â€”
" Oh dismal f â€¢â€¢ e; a dying mother dreads to see her Children.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh not to you, to me they owe their Ruin;
" Oh me, on me alone shou'd Vengeance fall.
" Add to my torments, heav'n, so they have ease.
" Oh! tho' she curst me still, tho' she ne're knew
" 'Twas for their good I strove to wed Placentia,
I'd bear an age of Hell to mend your fates.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Amazement! his guilt lessens. Can it be?
He pities me, pities my Children too.
Take back thy pity, take it back, Ricardo.
It gains so much upon my easy heart
That I shall wrong my self, and give thee mine.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Pity'd! am I then pityd? oh! thou goodness,
If thou can'st pity, sure thou can'st forgive,â€”
But oh the poyson! That must wake Heav'ns Vengeance,
And seal the ears of mercy;

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Twas Charity to kill me: but thy falshood
Was a worse poyson to my doating heartâ€”
Yet we've all faults. Alas, we all want mercyâ€”
We must forgive,â€”heav'n pardon thee, and me!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But fly! my Children's sight may force forgiveness back.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Is that forgiveness? see, I bleed apace.
Oh pardon, e're I dye.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh! I've a vice of mercy in me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Let me Embrace your Knees, breath out my Soul.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My Children! off, away.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I dare not see 'em, and I cannot leave her!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: " Away, you dearfond wretches. Why d' you cling?
" I've ruin'd you; but oh! I'm ruin'd worse.
" Poor Innocents, they little know their misery,
" I feel it double for them, wretched Mother.
Oh had my Woes fall'n only on my self,
I'd think 'em gentle, but this worse affliction
Intail'd on you, poor helpless guiltless Orphans,
It turns my Brains, distracts meâ€”'Tis too much.
Oh dreadful change! oh vanity of life!
Death is the only blessing a fond Mother
sp.stage: [She falls, and then she sees the Dagger by her and takes it up privately.
sp.l: Can wish her dearest Childrenâ€”ha! the Dagger.
Do's not Fate hint by this, I ought to ease 'em?
Must they be left, to want? to beg? to starve?
I'll do't; but oh what Arm can hurt such sweetness?
I cannot strikeâ€”I cannot bear their Looksâ€”
But must they live to curse me, shame their name,
And dye perhaps an ignominious Death?
No, I must strikeâ€”

sp.speaker: 1. Child.
sp.l: Pray, mother, don't look so, indeed it frights me
Oh pray ben't angry! oh I'll hug and kiss you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Away, we're ruin'd, and we ought to dye.

sp.speaker: 1. Child.
sp.l: Oh my dear Mother, live; We'll beg for you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Beg! cou'd you Beg?

sp.speaker: 1. Child.
sp.l: Yes, for our dearest mother.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh this disarms me. Live, my dearest Childrenâ€”
Live and be happier, you instruct your Mother,
sp.stage: (She throws away the Dagger and embraces her Children.
sp.l: And I too ought to Liveâ€”If there be meansâ€”but oh the poyson
It works, hah! it shoots Hell into my Blood!
I am all wound. My head; my breast! I burn!
Heart, I cleave my sides! Brains, burst my skull! help! help!
Oh gently, gently!â€”

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Oh horror! Curse thy sufferings off on me,
" Thou martyr'd Goodnessâ€”hurl your Bolts, you Powers!
" Grind, grind me into dust,
" And on each atom double all her pains.
" So Laura's eas'd, Ricardo will not murmur!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh! give me ease! where's Death?
The Coward dares not come, affrighted at my torments.
My Br â€¢â€¢ th's a fire. Help! Water, Ice! Heav'n, pity me.
Give ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ some of the cold my Children are to suffer.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Take hence these innocents, too much they move.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Oh pity themâ€”I call'd on Death, and lo, he's come at last.
But oh the thoughts of them, makes me now welcome him
With that sad heaviness that sinks despairing Sinners.
Oh Heav'n!â€”Oh my Children!â€”

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: She's dead, she's dead.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: " Hah! and do I still live?
" Be dry my Eyes, and you, my Wounds, weep faster.
" Oh let me look, and sigh my last at once.
Oh killing sight when shall I overtake thee,
Thou only fair? Oh! never, never, never.
'Tis not for guilt like mine to mount with thee:
I feel my self in Hell, and mercy's self
Can never stoop so low.
" Fain wou'd I prayâ€”ha! a Grim Vision frights me.
" Oh heav'n! oh save me! hah! a hand is stretcht
" To raise me up to heav'n, let me get holdâ€”
" But oh! dark vapours rise betweenâ€”I cannot see it
No News yet of Vincentio?â€”Oh most dismal sight!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Remove that Scene of Griefâ€”force off that wretch.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Oh you shall never part usâ€”No, I will, I will
Be joyn'd with her at least in Death!â€”Oh Laura! Laura,

div.stage: (Laura is carried off, Ricardo follows, bolding by the garments, but is forced off, faints, falls and is carried off.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A doleful Scene! but where's my Lord Vincentio.
I dread some greater mischief from his Stay.

sp.speaker: Zem.
sp.l: Run, find Placentia? Don Vincentio's coming,
A Conqu'ror o're his noble self at last.
He brings my Lord Fabiano to be blest.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Son!

div.stage: Enter Vincentio and Fabiano at one Doorâ–ª
Placentia, Morella, and Melinda at the other.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Love's sacrific'd at last to Reason, Take her,
She's yours, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Oh 'tis too much at onceâ€”oh raptureâ€”oh Placentia.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh my lov'd Lord!â€”

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: My Life! my Soul! oh I am lost in Bliss, and suffer with delight.
Thou kind omnipotence, forgive my doubts,
I thought thou cou'dst not thus have blest a mortalâ€”
My Lord, my Father!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh my dear Son, be blest, and let my tears
Now speak my Joy as once they did my Grief.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Thus Providence has wrought my desperate cure.
Oh! you, no more my Mistress nor my Rival,
Live happy. Long be crown'd
With blessings which no single state can give.
My heart has fed so long on hopeless Love
That it wou'd surfeit, shou'd it feed on other.
Glory shall be my Darling Mistress now.
Off then, soft frenzy! let me rouze my Soul.
In martial Fields let Fame possess it whole:
While all who know, whence sprung these dangers here,
Learn from small Crimes great mischiefs to beware.
